page.title: 15LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Brompton was a Saxon settlement.In 1086 Brinton,then Brumpton(Broom farm) until the C19th.,was held by the Bishops of Durham,but 'laid to waste'. St.Thomas's Church is over 1000 years old & became a Parish Church in 1843. Rare Viking hogback gravestones & Saxon crosses were found during the extensive Victorian restoration of the church.In 1138 the Battle of the Standard took place in the parish.John Kettlewell left a Trust in 1695 from which local scholars,sick & needy still benefit.The Whitsuntide Fair is still held on High Green.The railway brought crowds from Teesside to enjoy boating on the dammed up beck at Water End.Although an agricultural village,the railway's arrival in 1846 encouraged a thriving linen industry for the next 100 years.
